Field Label:
Which one of the following findings, consistent with diagnoses pulmonary tuberculosis, pneumonia, or bronchiolitis were noted on the CXR? (Select all that apply)

 

[For TB X-ray pictorial examples see https://informaproject site.github.io/INFORM/]
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, Normal | 2, Airway compression or tracheal compression | 3, Soft tissue density suggestive of lymphadenopathy | 4, Air space opacification or Consolidation - A dense fluffy opacity occupying a portion or the whole of a lobe or of entire lung that may or may not contain air bronchograms | 5, Other infiltrate - Linear and patchy densities (interstitial infiltrate) in a lacy pattern involving both lung fields, featuring peribronchial thickening and multiple areas of atelectasis that are not of sufficient magnitude to constitute primary endpoint consolidation, and small areas of atelectasis which, in children, may be difficult to distinguish from consolidation. | 6, Nodular appearance, miliary or larger, that is diffuse and bilateral | 7, Pleural effusion - Presence of fluid in the lateral pleural space between the lung and the chest wall; in most cases this will be seen in the costophrenic angle or as a layer of fluid adjacent to the lateral chest wall; this does not include fluid noted in the horizontal or oblique fissures. | 8, Evidence of hyperinflation on CXR (> 8 posterior ribs above the diaphragm) | 9, Cavitary Lesion(s) | 10, Calcified parenchyma (Ghon focus) | 11, Vertebral spondylitis | 12, Uninterpretable - Features of the image are not interpretable with respect to the presence or absence of consolidation and/or other infiltrates

Instructions: Do not enter commas. If no white blood cells (WBCs) were detected, please enter 0
Please indicate how many white blood cells per mm3 were detected in the CSF

Instructions: Do not enter commas. If no red blood cells (RBCs) were detected, please enter 0.

Please round the red blood cell count to the nearest whole number when recording results (e.g if RBCs are reported as 1537.2, please report as 1537).
Please indicate how many red blood cells per mm3 were detected in the CSF

Instructions: CSF protein concentration will be considered in the algorithm for meningitis certainty of diagnosis if a pathogen is not identified in the CSF or blood culture. Criteria for elevated protein in CSF is based on published pediatric infectious disease literature.4 A CSF protein level > 0.6 g/L for infants 29 days to 3 months, or > 0.4 g/L for children > 3 months of age will be considered consistent with meningitis
Please indicate the CSF protein level.

Instructions: CSF glucose will be considered in the algorithm for meningitis certainty of diagnosis if a pathogen is not identified in the CSF or blood culture. Criteria for low protein in CSF is based on published pediatric infectious disease literature. A CSF glucose level < 0.2 mmol/L in children < 6 months of age or < 2.4 mmol/L in children ≥ 6 months of age will be considered consistent with meningitis. If the CSF glucose value is reported in mg/dL, multiple the value by 0.0555 to ascertain the glucose level in mmol/L.

If the value of CSF glucose is < 1, please enter a leading zero, followed by a decimal point and the value. If the value is ≥ 1, enter the value followed by a decimal point any additional value up to the nearest one hundredth.
Please indicate the CSF glucose level.
Was a parasitic-based diagnostic test, either microscopy or rapid diagnostic test, used to evaluate this child for a diagnosis of malaria?
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, Yes | 0, No | 9, Unknown

Field Label: What was the result of the parasitic diagnostic test positive for malaria?
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, Yes | 0, No | 9, Unknown

Field Label: General Instructions: In some settings, parasitic diagnostic testing may not be available, the World Health Organizationís Integrated Management of Childhood Illness has identified laboratory signs of malaria including anemia, metabolic acidosis, hypoglycemia, indirect hyperbilirubinemia, and acute renal failure. Values that our outside the normal range according to the Division of AIDS (DAIDS) Table for Grading of Severity of Adult and Pediatric Adverse Events will be used to assess for lab abnormalities consistent with a diagnosis of malaria
Was a full blood count obtained?  This is often called a complete blood count in some settings
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, Yes | 0, No | 9, Unknown

Field Label: Instructions: Hemoglobin varies by age. a value of hemoglobin < 5.88 mmol/L (9.5 g/dL) in infants 29 0- 35 days old and those ≥ 57 days of age is consistent with anemia, whereas infants ≥ 36 days of life to ≤ 56 days of life with a hemoglobin of < 5.26 mmol/L (8.5 mg/dL) are considered to be anemic

Please indicate the hemoglobin level in mmol/L. To convert a hemoglobin level from mg/dL to mmol/L multiple the value by 0.6188.

Enter the value with a decimal point and report out to the hundredth, if that level of precision is available.
Was a chemistry obtained?
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, Yes | 0, No | 9, Unknown

Field Label: Instructions: The presence of a metabolic acidosis in a child suspected of having malaria represents one of the WHO criteria for diagnosis of malaria. Bicarbonate level will be used to assess for metabolic acidosis. DAIDS criteria for low bicarbonate is < 16.0 mmol/L or mEq/L

Please indicate the bicarbonate level (HC03).
(Same value whether reported as mmol/L or mEq/L)

 

Enter the value with a decimal point and report out to the nearest tenth, if that level of precision is available.

Instructions: The presence of a hypoglycemia in a child suspected of having malaria represents one of the WHO criteria for diagnosis of malaria. DAIDS criteria defines a glucose levels < 3.05 mmol/L (<55 mg/dL) among children 29 days of age or older to be consistent with grade 2 or higher hypoglycemia. If the value of glucose is reported in mg/dL, multiple the value by 0.0555 to ascertain the glucose level in mmol/L

Please indicate the glucose level.

Enter the value with a decimal point and report out to the nearest hundredth, if that level of precision is available.

Instructions: The presence of an indirect hyperbilirubinemia in a child suspected of having malaria represents one of the WHO criteria for diagnosis of malaria. However, indirect bilirubin values are usually derived from the difference between total bilirubin and direct bilirubin. In this case, DAIDS defines elevated total bilirubin as 1.6 x the upper limit of normal and direct bilirubin as greater than the upper limit of normal given variation in population characteristics. Therefore, the childís lab result with upper limit of normal for both total and direct bilirubin, in addition to the childís actual lab values for these will be required to calculate indirect hyperbilirubinemia. If direct bilirubin is not elevated above the upper limit of normal in the presence to elevation of total bilirubin, this will be deemed to reflect indirect hyperbilirubinemia.
Is the upper limit of normal for the lab value of total bilirubin available?

Please indicate the upper limit of a normal total bilirubin as reported by the lab in µmol/L. If the upper limit of normal is reported mg/dL, multiple this value by 17.1 to convert it to µmol/L

Enter the value with a decimal point and report out to the nearest tenth, if that level of precision is available
Field Note: Upper Limit of Normal for Total Bilirubin (µmol/L)

Field Label:

Enter the value with a decimal point and report out to the nearest tenth, if that level of precision is available.
Is the upper limit of normal for the lab value of direct bilirubin available?

Please indicate the upper limit of a normal direct bilirubin as reported by the lab in µmol/L. If the upper limit of normal is reported mg/dL, multiply this value by 17.1 to convert it to µmol/L

Enter the value with a decimal point and report out to the nearest tenth, if that level of precision is available
Field Note: Upper Limit of Normal for Direct Bilirubin (µmol/L)

Field Label:
Please indicate the direct bilirubin value reported for this child. If the upper limit of normal is reported mg/dL, multiple this value by 17.1 to convert it to µmol/L

Enter the value with a decimal point and report out to the nearest tenth, if that level of precision is available.

Instructions: The presence of an acute renal failure in a child suspected of having malaria represents one of the WHO criteria for diagnosis of malaria. Elevated creatinine can be used as a measure of acute renal failure. DAIDS defines elevated creatinine in two ways, either as more than 1.3 x the upper limit of normal or a 10% decrease or more from a child's baseline. As baseline values of creatinine are less likely to be available, this INFORM instrument will rely on increase in creatinine above the upper limit of normal only, and not a change from baseline.
Is the upper limit of normal for the lab value of creatinine available?

Please indicate the upper limit of creatinine as reported by the lab in µmol/L. If the upper limit of normal is reported mg/dL, multiple this value by 88 to convert it to µmol/L.

Enter the value with a decimal point and report out to the nearest tenth, if that level of precision is available.
Field Note: Upper Limit of Normal for Creatinine (µmol/L

Field Label:
Please indicate the creatinine value reported for this child. If the upper limit of normal is reported mg/dL, multiple this value by 88 to convert it to µmol/L.

Enter the value with a decimal point and report out to the nearest tenth, if that level of precision is available.
